I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Domestic resource mobilization through sound tax policy and administration is a key 
pillar for sustainable development. It is particularly relevant in developing Asia, where a large 
number of revenue authorities have low tax collection rates. The objective of this technical 
assistance (TA) is to increase capacity for better informed tax policy and administration. An 
important dimension of the TA will be knowledge sharing across Asia and the Pacific. Appendix 
1 contains a detailed design and monitoring framework.1 
 
2.  Public financial management, including tax administration and policy, is a core thematic 
priority under the Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), which is mainstreamed throughout ADB operations. Moreover, ADB’s Strategy 
2020 emphasizes good governance, capacity development, and partnership as key drivers of 
change.2 Tax administration is an important tool for strengthening governance, which is also a 
component of the regional public goods pillar of ADB’s regional cooperation and integration 
strategy. 
 
3.  For  ADB  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  to  reform  their  tax  policies  and 
administration, and for ADB to provide relevant advice to DMCs, it is essential to have basic 
information on internationally comparable data and practices. This information will help DMCs to 
identify issues relating to domestic revenue mobilization. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The G20’s Action Plan on Development initiated at the G20 Seoul Summit in November 
2010 adopted “domestic resource mobilization” as one of the nine development pillars.3 The 
Action Plan noted that “it is essential to continue to strengthen tax regimes and fiscal policies in 
developing countries to provide a sustainable revenue base for inclusive growth and social 
equity, as well as to enhance the transparency and accountability of public finances.” The G20 
specifically asked international and regional organizations to (i) support the development of 
more effective tax systems, and (ii) work to prevent erosion of domestic tax revenues. 
 
5.  Total tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) is low in developing 
Asia, averaging 17.8% in 1994–2012 compared to 36.7% for advanced economies.4 In many 
Asian countries, this is partly because of capacity constraints. A large shadow economy in 
developing  Asia  is  also  a  contributing  factor.5 According  to  Global  Financial  Integrity,  a 
Washington-based nongovernment organization, developing countries lost a total of $5.6 trillion 
in  illicit financial  outflows,  including tax  evasion,  in  2001–2010.  Asia is  estimated  to  have 
accounted for 61% of the total illicit outflows.6

6.  Internationally comparable data and information on benchmarks and good practices are 
essential  to  formulating  tax  policy  and  tax  administration  reform  options.  But  comparative 
information on tax policy and administration in Asia and the Pacific remains scarce despite 
growing demand from DMCs’ revenue authorities and international organizations.7 A report by 
international  organizations,  including  the  International  Monetary  Fund,  the  Organisation  for 
Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the United Nations, and the World Bank, to 
the G20 Cannes Summit in November 2011 pointed out that knowledge accumulation on tax 
systems  in  Asia  is  extremely  limited  compared  to  such  other  regions  as  Africa  and  Latin 
America. The report encouraged ADB to take on a greater role in this area.8 
 
7.  To enhance tax policy and administration in Asia and the Pacific, a regional approach 
can be effective whereby developing member countries share knowledge and practices with one 
another as well as with developed countries. While there is already a regional forum for tax 
administration bodies in East Asia, Southeast Asia, and Oceania (the Study Group on Asian Tax 
Administration and Research), the lack of a permanent secretariat limits that study group’s 
medium-term research functions.9  
 
8.  There  is  momentum,  therefore,  for  ADB  to  take  an  initial  step  on  research  and 
knowledge sharing in the tax area that will help DMCs to identify issues to be explored by their 
own tax policy makers and administrators as well as through ADB country-level operations. 
Further regional initiatives in this area might also be pursued.  
 
9.  Tax  administration  bodies  of  Brunei  Darussalam;  Cambodia;  Kyrgyz  Republic;  Lao 
People’s  Democratic  Republic;  Maldives;  Mongolia;  Papua  New  Guinea;  Philippines; 
Taipei,China; Tajikistan; and Thailand have already provided ADB with information on their tax 
administration  bodies’  functions  and  performance.  Moreover,  the  OECD  has  collected  and 
shared with ADB information on tax administration from Australia; People’s Republic of China; 
Hong Kong, China; India; Indonesia; Japan; Republic of Korea; Malaysia; New Zealand; and 
Singapore. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be better designed tax policy and administration and increased tax 
revenue collection in participant developing member countries. The outcome will be better 
informed participant DMCs with respect to tax policy and administration reform options. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have four outputs: 
(i)  Comparative analysis of tax administration in Asia and the Pacific. The 
report will gather data and provide an initial analysis report of tax administration

bodies’  regulatory  frameworks,  functions,  and  performance.10 Data  will  be 
collected through survey forms to be completed by tax authorities. The analysis 
will  be  mainly  descriptive.  A  regional  workshop  to  share  international  good 
practices will also be held. 
(ii)  Capacity  development  activities  for  ministries  of  finance  and  tax 
administration officials. These activities will support regional training seminars 
to be conducted jointly with other international organizations, including the OECD.  
(iii)  Tax revenue statistics in Asia. These statistics will compile and analyze annual 
revenue data in selected DMCs while breaking down such major tax items as 
income  taxes  and  indirect  taxes  (including  value-added  taxes)  using  an 
internationally comparable methodology.11 
(iv)  Empirical analysis of tax administration performance in Asia. The study will 
undertake econometric estimations to evaluate countries’ performance through a 
cross-country analysis of data collected by outputs (i) and (iii). 
 
12.  The TA assumes that tax policy and administration reform is a priority for DMCs and that 
DMCs  are  willing to  provide  and  share  information. The  main  risk  is that  information  and 
knowledge shared is not immediately reflected in the DMCs’ tax policy and administration 
reform process. To mitigate this risk, a follow-up evaluation at the end of the TA will include an 
assessment on demand and feasibility for continuous engagements. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $300,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
ADB Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency, while ADB’s Economics and Research Department 
(ERD)  and  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  (RSDD)  will  be  the 
implementing agencies. A senior economist at ERD and a public management specialist at 
RSDD will be responsible as team leaders for implementation of the TA. ERD and RSDD will be 
jointly responsible for the delivery of outputs (i) to (iii). ERD will be responsible to deliver output 
(iv). ERD will also play the principal role in administering and supervising the TA. Any changes 
in the responsibility for delivery of the expected outputs after TA approval will be processed in 
accordance with ADB project administration instructions on administering grant-financed TA.12 
 
15.  The TA has been designed with input from ADB regional departments and resident 
missions, and their continued input will be sought throughout implementation of the TA. 
 
16.  Four international tax policy experts will be required for 9.8 person-months to compile 
the revenue statistics data for output (iii) and to draft the report (cost: $129,700 for remuneration

and per diem, and $12,000 for travel). Two editors will be needed for 1 person-month to edit the 
reports for outputs (i) and (iii) (cost: $13,200). Two national consultants (3 person-months) will 
be needed for desktop publishing and graphic design of the two publications (cost: $7,100). 
 
17.  Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  for  assignments,  as  the  TA  will  require 
country-specific analysis and rapid mobilization of the editorial consultants. ADB will hire the 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time) using the individual consultant system. Disbursements under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Dissemination activities will be conducted in cooperation with ADB’s Department 
of External Relations. All the procurement to be financed under the TA will be carried out in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The OECD’s Centre for Tax Policy and Administration and its Development Centre will 
cooperate with ADB in implementing the TA. The OECD will provide in-kind contributions, such 
as assisting with information and data collection from participant countries, drafting publications, 
and organizing training seminars. The OECD is not expected to make a financial contribution to 
the TA. 
 
19.  Appropriate monitoring and evaluation tools will be developed to ensure all consultants 
engaged in the TA perform their tasks as outlined in the terms of reference. Internal and 
external peer review will be used to evaluate the reports’ quality and depth of analysis. The 
production schedule will be closely monitored to ensure that the established deadlines are met 
for the timely printing and delivery of the publications. Event evaluations will be conducted for 
the workshop and training seminars. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented from 19 September 2013 and be completed by 30 June 
2015.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Tax Policy and Administration Research and Capacity Development, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

10  Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE OF THE COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS REPORT ON TAX ADMINISTRATION IN 
ASIA AND THE PACIFIC 
 
1.  Institutional arrangements for tax administration 
(i)  Are  tax  administration  bodies  parts  of  the  ministries  of  finance  or  semi-
autonomous bodies? 
(ii)  Do  tax  administration  bodies  have  non-taxation  functions,  such  as  customs 
collection, student loan administration? 
(iii)  What kinds of administrative functions do tax administration bodies have? Do 
they have discretion to design internal organization, to hire and fire staff, and/or 
to spend budgets?  
 
2.  Internal organization of tax administration bodies 
(i)  How  is  the  organization  of  tax  administration  bodies  designed,  for  instance, 
based on tax laws, by administration functions, or by taxpayer segments?  
(ii)  Do tax administration bodies have large taxpayer units?  
(iii)  How many tax offices do tax administration bodies have?  
 
3.  Human resources management 
(i)  What are the total numbers of staff in tax administration bodies?  
(ii)  What are the numbers of staff as classified by functions (e.g., audit, enforced 
debt collection, taxpayer account management)? 
(iii)  What are the staff attrition and retention rates of tax administration bodies? Are 
tax  administration  bodies  successfully  retaining  high-caliber  staff  using 
competitive salary schemes?  
 
4.  Budget and expenditure 
(i)  What are the total annual expenditures of tax administration bodies?  
(ii)  What are the expenditures on staff costs and operations related to information 
technology? 
 
5.  Revenue and GDP statistics 
(i)  How much tax revenues do tax administration bodies collect? 
(ii)  What is the break down by major tax types (i.e., personal and corporate income 
taxes, value-added taxes (VAT), sales taxes, social security contributions)? 
(iii)  What percentages of gross VAT collected are refunded?  
 
6.  Taxpayer identification and filing 
(i)  How many taxpayers are registered for corporate and individual income taxes 
and for VAT?  
(ii)  What percentages of tax returns are prepared by tax agents? 
(iii)  Are  taxpayer  identifiers  (taxpayer  numbers)  distributed  for  tax  administration 
purposes?   
(iv)  Are  taxpayer  identifiers  required  to  be  used  when  employers  or  banks  pay 
salaries or interest to taxpayers? 
 
7.  Information and communication technology and electronic services 
(i)  Do tax administration bodies have separate and substantial in-house information 
technology functions? 
(ii)  Can tax declarations be submitted electronically? What are the penetration (take 
up) rates for personal and corporate income taxes and for VAT?

Appendix 4  11 
(iii)  Can taxes be paid electronically? What methods are available (e.g., internet 
banking, phone banking)?  
 
8.  Audits 
(i)  What are the numbers of tax audits (verification), and the amounts of taxes 
raised as a result of verification actions?  
(ii)  Do tax administration bodies have substantial information gathering and search 
powers?  For  example, do  tax  administration  bodies  have general  powers  to 
obtain all relevant information, and can these powers be extended to third parties? 
Can  tax  officials  enter  taxpayers’  business  premises  and  seize  documents 
without taxpayers’ consent and without a search warrant? 
 
9.  Arrears collection 
(i)  What are the numbers of cases and values of tax arrears (unpaid tax)? 
(ii)  What kinds of debt collection powers do tax administration bodies have? Can tax 
revenue bodies seize assets or publicize the names of debtor taxpayers in the 
media? 
 
10.  Administrative arrangements for tax disputes  
(i)  Are there administrative review procedures in addition to judicial procedures? If 
so,  are  administrative  review  procedures  provided  by  the  revenue  bodies 
themselves or by separate government organizations?   
(ii)  What  are  the  numbers  and  tax  values  of  cases  in  administrative  review 
procedures?
